comments.commentBody: One epistemological problem presented by Wittgenstein, which could in turn become a contradiction is that he flip-flops on the existence of other minds. At one point he asserts that we can never know for sure whether there is such a thing as a mind at all, then in another he claims that minds are something of which human beings can be directly aware of. Thus minds become something like an optical illusion, being say a duck at one point or a rabbit at another. Of course descriptivism is powerful, but it cannot undermine all of philosophy (such as the branch of epistemology), which is a necessary component of arriving at a descriptivist account of anything to begin with.

There is a real difference between the present mayor of Newark NJ and most of his predecessors, particularly the one who traded a seat in the House of Representatives for being Newark's mayor because there was more money to be made in that position.

Good theory, but facts trouble it.

China does not have technology that our companies would want to steal, so we don't. However, China has many cyber secrets that we do want to learn, and China is loudly complaining that we started and continue these cyber attacks by breaking into their systems.

Nobody who is in public print can claim to know just what our intelligence agencies have been doing by way of cyber attacks in China, but we do have a lot of agencies well equipped to do it. Do we want to stop? Really? Or do we only want them to stop while we do as we like?

It is the same for the permanent political campaign. Both sides do it. Neither side actually wants to stop. The individual politicians in place got there and have stayed there by these abuses, and are the last persons who would want to destroy the system that produces their re-election.

We might well be better off in a world without the cyber wars. If so, we must be prepared to live with the rules we propose. Then we can agree on them and enforce them by treaty.

The American public would be better served by a politics without the huge influence of cash flows to politicians. If so, the American public must impose laws on our politicians to ban it, and see they are enforced. This would probably require Proposals by Initiative in each state, because the individual politicians now in office actually don't want to stop -- they already are beholden, wholly owned by their contributors.

Such a loving son. Sharing his life with his parents when he can, no matter the distance he has to travel to reach his family.

His journey shows a faithfulness and steadfastness that is quite remarkable. A man of uncommon grace, even perhaps of the "amazing" variety.

Mr. Bruni, I concur. Jeff gives me hope, too.

I would suggest finding a doctor who specializes in ADD. Pediatricians often prescribe these drugs but aren't as familiar as someone who only deals with this medical specialty. Constant supervision is a must.

It can take some trial and error before the proper medication (there are several) and dosage are established. This changes with age, however.
Calling this a "hoax" or "childish prank" does not make the actions any less offensive. Do men have to gallop in on horses and white hoods to label the actions racist and homophobic?
There have been many other fakes ... Claremont McKenna comes to mind, among others.
Speculation leading to a conclusion without evidence .
Cool illustration bro. Pics or it didn't happen.

Dennis Overbye and the New York Times have done a wonderful job making this fascinating and important story accessible. Thank you!

I hope it wins Mr. Overbye a Pulitzer, and I would like to read the book he ought to write about the Higgs search and discovery.
Amazing report. We need more Big Science!
They sure are. But not the ones you mean.

It is thoroughly entertaining to hear our elitists claim that a third of one percent lopped off our budget (doubled since 2000) is sufficient to knock hundreds of thousands of people out of jobs. What would a full one precent do? Reverse the tides of the ocean? I must suppose a balanced budget would invoke a total rearrangement of the Earth's surface or something ... or else, people are being played.

Again.

Americans do need jobs. Corporations send jobs to China. Corporations get favorable tax treatment and are not penalized for not actually creating jobs in spite of record profits. Unemployed Americans hate the rich. No Kool-Aid needed.

The definition of 'normal' is rather fluid, and behavior that would be considered normal by some is certainly not, according to others. Is there only one 'right' way for a mind to work, or do different processing algorithms exist? Living in a society where it seems that everything has a cure, some drug that will conquer what ails you, the pressure to perform often leads people to substance abuse. We used to live in groups where unusual behavior was noticed quickly, and investigated, but now someone can live their lives isolated and alone. In such situations, we can lose a great deal of ourselves without anyone stepping in to see if we are alright.

The drug is not at fault, nor does the writer shoulder all of the blame. Our society is so twisted and unnatural that doing drugs to meet performance expectations is not considered unusual to many. This kind of abuse is even more likely as productivity is demanded in ever higher quantities.

Doris,

Doug Rife pointed mentioned high income/ high net worth people who chose to self insure. Presumably because they wouldn't be ruined by high medical bills.

People who are relatively well off but cannot afford huge hospital bills should have insurance. There is no excuse.

For the people who don't stay healthy and don't buy insurance, the calculation they made to not pay into the system worked for them. It saved them money. That money would have gone into paying claims for people who did get sick.

If healthy people don't subsidize sick people, it means that sick people are going to pay more.

While fixing the problem of hospitals overcharging people who are uninsured or underinsured is nice, the real solution is not to have uninsured or underinsured people to begin with and to have insurance be affordable by making the cost be a percentage of one's income.

I just reread the article that you linked to and I still can't believe you
based your argument on that article, that has no references, and refutes itself. I want to be fair, because I the past I've enjoyed reading you. This is a hatchet job. You must have compelling reasons to write this, but it seems that your heart wasn't in it.

Joe,
The link in your article had a sublink that was not clear about whether the Venezuelan oil is in fact dirtier than tar sands. It seemed to imply that Mexican crude and tar sands were both dirtier than oil from Venezuela. If that is true, the whole article is suspect. You need to get cleaner facts.

Dividends and capital gains and inheritances should all be taxed as ordinary income or higher. I think so, and Lincoln thought so, too.

That would take a step towards fairness in the tax system and remove the carried interest issue as well. As Nobel prizewinning economist Stiglitz points out in his informative book The Price of Inequality, the rich 1% and the super-rich 1.10 of 1% pay a lower actual tax rate on their income than the middle class and the lower income classes. That is obscene.

www.youtube.com/tra1776

Joe, your columns about the XL Pipeline are surprising, from a man who advocates such a sensible and concerned approach to gun regulation.

Climate change, whether one agrees with the 350 ppm concentration of carbon dioxide as the tipping point, our climate is undergoing profound change. Witness the Arctic, where the sought for Northwest Passage of the 19th century has become a reality with its rapidly shrinking ice mass and now open waters for part of the year. There is concern that the increasing retreat of glaciers world wide will have significant impacts, such as in and around the Himalayas, with its water flow from glaciers feeding the thirst of over one billion human beings.

Burning fossil fuels adds significantly to the concentration of atmospheric CO2. Your initial approach to the XL pipeline was that the energy provided from it was necessary for our country's energy independence. Your new approach is that James Hansen is doing the cause of climate change great harm by his insistence that the XL pipeline is an enterprise fraught with dangers for air and water.

Isn't that what activists do, bring to the public's attention matters of urgency? If James Hansen does not have the credentials to speak about this, who does?

It is not shocking to me. What shocked me was how little property tax is paid on Sandy Weill's former condo (the one sold to a Russian oligarch). I think the tax was under $100,000 per year for a condo worth about $88 MILLION.
Clocks back then did not show tenths of a second and many were still analog clocks, (with a second hand going around the clock face), but it's still a great story and memory....

Great story and YouTube film. History records an almost an exact circumstance in the 1962 New York City Catholic High School semi-final city championship between Kareem Abdul Jabbar's (Lew Alcindor) Power Memorial High School and St. John's Prep. A shot left the hand of Power's Johnny Hayes with 0.1 seconds remaining which traveled at least 45 feet from other half of court, but did not drill through the rim immediately like this shot by Khalil Edney. Hayes's shot bounced off the front rim, then the backboard, then the rim again and rolled in for a 49-48 last split second win for Power Memorial. I doubt there was film of it, but a person never knows with such a story that seems like ancient history. I played for St. John's and will always remember the Hayes shot as will Khalil remember his in 2013.

What a great shot! Way to follow up the inbounds pass. He helped make
his own luck.

Said no doubt by a white man who is clueless about the racism that still is alive
and well in America.

"There is such a hunger in 2013 to sniff out racists and punish them..."

Seems like you pine for the good ol' days.

I had my son at the end of my 1st year as doctoral student in clinical psychology, attending a school in NYC.  I was lucky to be due in spring and got to spend the summer with him before returning full time to school.  I'll never forget though, how I often had to pump (breastmilk) in a toilet stall between my back to back classes.  People were excreting in the adjacent stalls while I was trying to provide a wholesome meal for my son.   There was a single 'mother's room'  in another building about a 7 minute walk away, and no legislation or regulation providing for student mothers.  Who makes their kid's lunch in a toilet stall??!
Does that make it any less wrong?
He could go to Antioch instead. Or Emory. Or Claremont McKenna ....

Wouldn't they need to identify who is responsible before considering appropriate action?  You act as though the administration is condoning these acts because they have chosen to address the issue publicly.  Since they haven't caught the perpetrators yet, it's a little soon to condemn the response.
